lines.content: For this project, I used Claude as a tool to validate and review my programs. In particular, it assisted me with:
3. Generating test cases and adding assertions for defensive programming
4. Resolving numerous Checkstyle issues that were initially overwhelming

Through this process, I learned several best practices that I would not have applied on my own. Despite having been introduced to `Optional` and Streams in CS2030S, I had not internalised their practical use. Using them in this project helped me better understand how they improve null-safety, readability, and functional composition. I also gained hands-on experience with wildcards and enums, which strengthened the type safety and expressiveness of my program.

I was initially hesitant about relying on AI for iP, as I felt it might diminish the learning experience. However, I found that using AI as a review and guidance tool - rather than a code generator - helped me learn language features and design practices that I had limited exposure to. As a PLT enthusiast, I found it especially rewarding to apply these constructs in a way that improved the robustness and clarity of my program.
Overall, the experience deepened my understanding of Java's type system and modern idioms, and helped me adopt better software engineering practices.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Yappy_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
2. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
2. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
3. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.

3. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).`
`
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

4. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Yappy.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Yappy.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
